lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can revise the question word “what” and form correct question sentences.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write wh- questions: “What do you do?” “What do they eat?” Students match questions to answers on slips of paper.
stretchStrategies: Students create and swap “mystery job” questions using “what.” Example: “What does a ___ do?” Partner answers, then writes a new question for another classmate.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write questions using “what” accurately.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Write a question starter: “What…” and three job cards. Students create questions and write them: “What does a vet do?”
stretchStrategies: Students create and swap “mystery job” questions using “what.” Example: “What does a ___ do?” Partner answers, then writes a new question for another classmate.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can pronounce words with the “-ear” and “-air” sounds correctly.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Dictate: “clear, chair, pear.” Students write and underline the sound pattern. Practise saying words in pairs.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
